info.name: 0chain
info.description:
## What is 0chain
0Chain is decentralizing storage, providing a single source of truth for data, with unparalleled privacy, security, transparency and performance. Developers and Enterprises use 0Chain to

* Provide a single source of truth for documents, and
* Better protect data with high performance at no risk

[Explore More](https://www.0chain.net/)


## Value of ZCN
Value of ZCN is based on amount of data on the network and locked tokens. Token holders earn “Interest” tokens immediately when they lock ZCN. Miners earn multiple ways:

* Traditional Mining
* Providing Storage Service
* Interest ZCN when they Stake.

## 0chain's APIs
0chain's endpoints use simple and intuitive HTTP requests to intearct with the blockchain. These APIs/endpoints can be used to retrieve information from or send information to miners, sharders or blobbers in the active network.

This documentation explains each API/endpoint provided by 0chain. These can be used to create and manage

* Wallets
* Transactions
* Storage Allocations
* Other blockchain related requests


Contact Support:
 Email: zero@0chain.net

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

request.description:
Endpoint to get Balance of a wallet

**Response definition:**  

| Field        | Description           |
| ------------- |:-------------:|
| txn |  The latest transaction to execute against the wallet    |
| round | |
| balance | The wallet balance in mZCN |

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS
GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

request.description:
A wallet is registered or retrieved by sending a request to all miners on the network. 

For en example of how this endpoint can be used, see the [Create a wallet](#7bb3f72f-b7cb-44c8-b40d-2b96ad6d0534) example

**Response definition:**  

| Field        | Description           |
| ------------- |:-------------:|
| id |  The wallet id (which is a SHA1-256 hash of the public key)   |
| version | The wallet version |
| creation_date | The date the wallet was registered in the unix epoch (seconds) format |
| public_key | The BLS public key |

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

response.name: invalid client id or public key

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

request.description:
Commit an action on 0chain's storage platform.
To see this request in a wider context, see the [Upload Example](#ee4bc246-7bb3-4279-985d-f0706f0c14d3)

**Response definition:**  

| Field        | Description           |
| ------------- |:-------------:|
| allocation_root |  The new allocation root is the SHA1-256 hash of every file/directory in the allocation, appended together colon deliminated and the result SHA1-256 hashed again  |
| write_marker | A container object that details the most recent write operation to the allocation |

write_marker definition: 

| Field        | Description           |
| ------------- |:-------------:|
| prev_allocation_root | The allocation root before this marker was written |
| allocation_id | the allocation this write marker belongs to |
| size | the size of the most recent write in bytes |
| blobber_id | the blobber the write was performed on |
| timestamp | the time of the write in unix epoch seconds |
| client_id | the id of the wallet that performed the write |
| signature | the BLS signature of the writer |

response.name: unsuccessful commit - incorrect blobber

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

request.description:
Provides the latest magic block from 0dns

**Magic block response definition**

| Field        | Description           |
| ------------- |:-------------:|
| hash | hash of the block |
| previous_hash | previous hash of the block |
| magic_block_number | |
| starting_round | |
| miners | |
| shaders | |
| share_or_signs | |
| mpks | |
| t | |
| k | |
| n | |

response.name: successful operation

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

request.description:
Endpoint to get network details from 0dns

For an example of how this endpoint can be used, see the  
[Connect to the network](#43685d5b-430c-48f5-81f3-5d76063cee24) example

**Response definition**

| Field        | Description           |
| ------------- |:-------------:|
| miners | miners registered on the network |
| sharders | sharders registered on the network |

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

header.description: (required) The SHA1-256 hash of the allocation id, BLS signed

formdata.description: boolean whether or not this request is repairing a previous upload that has a missing shard
connecton id used to tie this upload to a future commit

request.description:
Upload a file to 0chain's storage platform.

To see this request in action, see the [Upload Example](#ee4bc246-7bb3-4279-985d-f0706f0c14d3)

**Response definition**

| Field        | Description           |
| ------------- |:-------------:|
| filename | the filename of the original file |
| size | the size of the uploaded shard |
| content_hash | the SHA3-256 hash of the uploaded shard |
| merkle_root | the merkle root for verification purposes |

header.description: The wallet public key hex string
(required) The SHA1-256 hash of the allocation id, BLS signed

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Content-Type header generated by Postman.

formdata.description: Specify true if you want to verify that the allocation is not under repair

request.description:
Update a file to 0chain's storage platform.  
The same request as an upload request with **updateMeta** instead of **uploadMeta**

**Response definition**  
as upload

header.description: The wallet public key hex string
(required) The SHA1-256 hash of the allocation id, BLS signed

formdata.description: Specify true if you want to verify that the allocation is not under repair

request.description:
Delete a file to 0chain's storage platform

**Response definition**  
as upload

Download a file from 0chain's storage platform

To see this request in a wider context, see the [Download Example](#363290db-0405-41fa-a010-eca355935d08)

**Response definition**  
Successful download: Raw file data  
Unsuccessful response: latest read marker

request.description:
Send a transaction to the miners to process.  
For examples of this endpoint in action, see the      
[Lock read tokens](#b8e5d107-0f5e-41bd-9202-c2582af01c49)  
[Create storage allocation](#30ddc13e-47a0-46fa-a598-308111adb920) and  
[Add test ZCN to wallet](#eac6f378-54f9-4623-bd2a-01b9549f36b9)  
examples

The SmartContractTxnData type of the transaction_data field contains the fields:

* name - defines the smart contract function
* input - contains value of one of the types described below. The specific type depends on the smart contract function.

Response in the transaction_output field of the SmartContractTxnOutput type. The specific type depends on the smart contract function.

Description in the table:

|SC function|Request|Response|
|-|-|-|
| *Miner Smart contract* |
| add_miner,add_sharder,update_settings,sharderKeep|minerNode |minerNode |        
| shareSignsOrShares | ShareOrSign | ShareOrSign |
| contributeMpk | MPK | MPK |
| addToDelegatePool | DelegatePool | text/plain |
| deleteFromDelegatePool| DelegatePool | DeleteFromDelegatePoolResult |        
| *Multisig Smart contract* |
| register| Wallet | text/plain: "success: multi-signature wallet registered"|
| vote|  MultisigVote | text/plain:  "success 0: transfer executed with signature ..."|        
| *Vesting Smart contract* |
| register | VestingPoolRequest | array of TokenPoolTransferResponse |
| unlock | VestingPoolRequest | TokenPoolTransferResponse |
| delete | VestingPoolRequest | VestingDeleteResult |
| add | VestingAddRequest | VestingPool |
| stop |  VestingStopRequest | plain/text |        
| *Interestpool Smart contract* |
| lock | InterestPoolNewRequest | Transfer |
| unlock | InterestPoolStat | Transfer |
| updateVariables | InterestPoolGlobalNode | InterestPoolGlobalNode |
| *Faucet Smart contract* |
| updateLimits | FaucetLimitRequest | FaucetGlobalNode |
| pour | Empty | Transfer |
| refill | Empty | Transfer|     
| *Storage Smart contract* |
| read_redeem | StorageReadConnection | text/plain: success |
| commit_connection | StorageBlobberCloseConnection | BlobberAllocation |
| new_allocation_request | StorageNewAllocationRequest | StorageAllocation |
| update_allocation_request | StorageUpdateAllocationRequest | StorageAllocation |
| finalize_allocation | StorageLockRequest| text/plain:finalized |
| cancel_allocation | StorageLockRequest| text/plain:canceled |
| add_blobber |  StorageNode | StorageNode |
| update_blobber_settings | StorageNode | StorageNode |
| add_validator | StorageValidationNode  | StorageValidationNode |
| blobber_health_check | Empty | StorageNode |
| new_read_pool | Empty |StorageReadPool |
| read_pool_lock | StorageLockRequest | Transfer |
| read_pool_unlock | StorageUnlockRequest | TokenPoolTransferResponse |
| write_pool_lock | StorageLockRequest | TokenPoolTransferResponse |
| write_pool_unlock | StorageUnlockRequest | TokenPoolTransferResponse |
| stake_pool_lock | StorageStakePoolRequest | Transfer |
| stake_pool_unlock | StorageStakePoolRequest | StorageStakePoolUnlockResponse |
| stake_pool_pay_interests | StorageStakePoolRequest  | text/plain: "interests has payed" |
| stake_pool_take_rewards | StorageStakePoolRequest | TokenPoolTransferResponse |
| generate_challenges | Empty | text/plain: "Challenges generated" |
| challenge_response | StorageChallengeResponse | Empty |
| update_config | StorageSmartContractConfig | Empty |

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

item.description:
The 0chain API is versioned through URI path in accordance with REST standards.  
The reference below is for **v1** of the API.

item.name: Examples
🖥️ Connect to the network
1. Get List of miners/sharders from the network

exec: // sets the miners and sharders we will be using for susequent examples to the first one returned from 0dns.
// in production, your system should send each request to all miners/sharders with a consensus requirement of 20% (recommended)
// or send to 20% of sharders with a consensus requirement of 100%.
console.log("Checkng that BLS example api is running. If not running it should be started within 60s of this call....")
Ensures the Example API required for inline functions such as encrypton and BLS is running
If this call fails or reaches a timeout, the example API server may be overloaded.
Please try again in a few minutes

request.description:
Retrieve a list of miners and sharders from the network.
Miners and sharders are used to interact with the network depending on the operation.

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

item.description:
The entry point to the decentralised network is the block worker.  
Te block worker will return a list of miners and sharders for the chain you wish to connect to which will be used for most other operations on the network.

The block worker itself is decentralised - anyone can run a mirror.

item.name: 🗂️ Create a wallet

exec: //Calculates a BLS BN254 public key from the 24 word seed in your postman environment.
//An external API is used for this calculation for the benefit of postman. In production
//this would be a call to a locally running library or service.
This function is for illustration/testing purposes only.
The API called within is not suitable for production calls and is provided without warranty.
Gets an 8-bit hex dump of the public key hex string
Ensure your SHA3-256 impl uses is standard, not keccak-256 (which is what CryptoJS uses)
Calling a custom API here as the hashify API does not support hex dump byte arrays, but this is widely supported by hashing libraries

request.description:
A wallet is registered or retrieved by sending a request to all miners on the network. 

**Requirements to make this request:**

**[BIP39](https://en.bitcoinwiki.org/wiki/Mnemonic_phrase) Mnemonic**: A 24 word representation of the wallet private key seed with a passphrase of "0chain-client-split-key".  There are [utilities](https://iancoleman.io/bip39/) that can help you generate this.  
**BLS BN254 private key:** Thee private key generated from the BIP39 mnemonic seed. 0Chain Keys are [BLS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BLS_digital_signature) with a [BN254 curve](https://neuromancer.sk/std/bn/bn254) . There are [many](https://github.com/herumi/bls) / [libraries](https://github.com/herumi/bls-wasm) to help you generate this key.  
**BLS BN254 public key hex string**: The public key calculated from the previously generated private key, formatted as a hex string.    
**Client/wallet id**:  A SHA3-256 hash of the public key **hex dump** - for an example of how this hex dump can be generated, see the pre-request script of this request in postman.  

A consensus of 20% is required from the miners, after which you can be sure that your request will be propagated.

The example below shows a single miner call but assumes the call will be made to all miners retrieved in step 1

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

item.description:
A wallet is registered or retrieved by sending a request to all miners on the network.  
A successful response from 20% of the miners also known as a consensus is required before a registration can be considered a success.

# Requirements
- Connect to the network

request.description:
**Requirements to make this request:**  
**Hash**
A SHA3-256 hash of a colon delimited string of [creation_date, client_id, to_client_id, transaction_value and the SHA3-256 hash of transaction_data]  
**Signature**
A BLS signature of the Hash  
**Client Id**
Your wallet id  
**Public Key**
The hex string of the BLS public key  
**Creation date**
The current unix epoch timestamp  
**To client Id**
The Id of the smart contract you wish to execute the transaction data on  
**Transaction data**
The default faucet transaction data

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

exec: //delay postman from sending the request for 7 seconds, this should give the network plenty of time to process the request

query.description: The hash of the faucet transaction

request.description:
After a transaction is submitted to the miners it is processed asynchronously.
Therefore we have to check it's status by calling the sharders.  
In a similar fashion to calling the miners, multiple sharders should be called and a consensus reached before considering a transaction as "processed".  
If the sharders do not return a 200 response with a hash after a few seconds, the transaction may have failed to process.

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

item.description:
The **faucet** smart contract on testnet enables you to send ZCN to your wallet for testing   
**Run this step multiple times to ensure your wallet has 3+ tokens for the remaining examples** 

A transaction request is made with the faucet smart contract data included

# Requirements
- Create a wallet

1. Create storage allocation with 60 min expiry

exec: // timestamp is in the unix epoch (seconds) format

request.description:
The following request asks the miners to create a storage allocation on the network.   
The transaction will need confirmed before it can be considered successful (next step)

**Requirements to make this request:**  
**Hash**
A SHA3-256 hash of a colon delimited string of [creation_date, client_id, to_client_id, transaction_value and the SHA3-256 hash of transaction_data]  
**Signature**
A BLS signature of the Hash  
**Client Id**
Your wallet id  
**Public Key**
The hex string of the BLS public key  
**Creation date**
The current unix epoch timestamp  
**To client Id**
The Id of the smart contract you wish to execute the transaction data on  
**Transaction data**
Allocation specific setup goes here such as number of data and parity shards and expiry time

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

query.description: The hash of the allocation that we have requested be created

request.description:
Similar to the faucet request, the create allocation request must be confirmed by a consensus of sharders before it can be considered created.  

The output of this confirmation will contain the allocation id under txn.transaction_output.id

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

item.description:
A storage allocation is an assignment of blobbers, with each blobber providing a set amount of storage space. Files are uploaded to an allocation and are deleted when the allocation expires.
The allocation is configurable in terms of expiry time, storage size, blobber performance, blobber geo-location, token cost and [erasure-coding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_Reed%E2%80%93Solomon_encoding) ratio.  

ZCN are locked for the duration of an allocation and the majority released after it expires.  
The amount of tokens required for an allocation depends on a number of factors including (but not limited to) how much storage space is required and the number of blobbers required (EC ratio).

# Requirements
- Create a wallet
- Add test ZCN to wallet

item.name: 📤 Upload a file

exec: // sets the data we need for subsequent requests.
// currently this is hardcoded for 4 blobbers for demonstration purposes.

request.description:
Retrieve the storage allocation detail by performing a GET operation on the smart contract.  
The result of this will be important information we need such as the number of data and parity shards as well as the id and url of each blobber in the allocation, which is where our data is uploaded to.

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

exec: // get the file hash and size from the API as well as parity and data shards.

formdata.description: This is not a 0chain api call but is analogous to using your programming language's read file function. Choose the file you wish to upload.

request.description:
After retrieving an allocation, the file should be processed for upload. 

Firstly, we need to record some file metadata: 
- the SHA1 hash of the file 
- the file size in bytes

We also need to Reed-Solomon erasure code the file into multiple shards. Each shard will be uploaded to a different blobber in the allocation.  

None of the above is natively supported in postman so is accomplished by calling an external API that will return the file size, SHA1 hash and reed-solomon EC shards.

The above data is trivial to calculate with a range of well supported libraries in most programming languages.

Please do not attempt to upload files > 10M in size as this is a limitation of postman. A text file is recommended so you can easily visualise the EC shards

exec: Ensure your SHA3-256 impl uses the SHA3 standard, not keccak-256 (which is what CryptoJS uses)
This function is for illustration/testing purposes only.
The API called within is not suitable for production calls and is provided without warranty.

request.description:
Once the file hash, size and EC shards have been calculated, the file can be uploaded by sending a multipart form to the blobber with the EC shard for that blobber.  

Remember that only the single EC shard for this blobber is uploaded, not the entire file.  

The below example shows a raw multipart form request which may be necessary if your library (such as postman!!) only supports full file upload 

However, in languages such as Java, partial binary is supported via streams in many libraries HTTP clients without requiring a raw form request to be created.  
  

**Requirements to make this request:**

**uploadFile**:  
The Reed-Solomon data shard from the previous step  
**connection_id**:  
A unique 9 digit integer id that will tie this upload to subsequent commit requests.  
**uploadMeta**
A JSON object containing metadata for the current request.Thee object must contain the following fields:  

| Field        | Description           |
| ------------- |:-------------:|
| connection_id | Same as above   |
| filename | The name of the destination file |
| filepath | The full destination file path |
| actual_hash | The SHA1 hash of the **original** file (not the current shard)   |
| actual_size | the size of the **original** file (not the current shard) in bytes |

header.description: The wallet public key hex string

item.name: 4. Get file reference path for EC shard

exec: Ensure your SHA3-256 impl uses the SHA3 standard, not keccak-256 (which is what CryptoJS uses)
This function is for illustration/testing purposes only.
The API called within is not suitable for production calls and is provided without warranty.

request.description: The file reference path details all files in the directory we are uploading to. It is important to have this information in the next step, as we will be inserting a new entry to this reference path and re-calculating it's hash

exec: //Add the current file to the file reference path and re-compute directory hashes.
//This requires data from the original upload request, the upload response and the file reference path.
async function addFileToTree(blobberReferencePath, uploadResult, uploadRequest, filePath) {

metaData.hash = await sha3256([allocationId, metaData.type, metaData.name, metaData.path, metaData.size, metaData.content_hash, metaData.merkle_root, metaData.actual_file_size, metaData.actual_file_hash, JSON.stringify(metaData.attributes)].join(":"))
var existingDir = blobberReferencePath.list.filter(e => dirName == e.meta_data.name && "d" == e.meta_data.type);
This function is for illustration/testing purposes only.
The API called within is not suitable for production calls and is provided without warranty.
Ensure your SHA3-256 impl uses the standard, not keccak-256 (which is what CryptoJS uses)
console.log("All Blobbers have successfully been committed to, resetting to bloebber 0")

formdata.description: The connection you wish to commit

request.description:
In a similar fashion to some databases, a file is not persisted permanently to the blobber until it is comitted.  
0Chain keeps it's network fast by storing data off-chain while maintaining the benefits of on-chain storage by comitting the allocation metadata to the blockchain.
  
A commit requires a write marker. Think of this as the latest entry in an audit trail containing the hash of the entire allocation at the time of upload and a link to the previous write market in the form of the hash of the previous allocation state.  

**This is a major benefit of 0chain - a GDPR compliant, transparent and immutable audit log is a mandatory feature of the platform.**  

**Requirements to make this request:**  
Create a new write marker using the reference path:
- Set previous allocation root to current allocation root 
- Traverse through file tree until file path is reached
- Add file metadata entry to that directory
- recalculate directory hash
- recalculate all parent directory hashes
- recalculate root directory hash

- set allocation root to root directory hash with timestamp
- BLS signature sign the request


Shard is now successfully uploaded to a blobber.

**Now Repeat steps 3, 4 and 5 for each remaining blobber, postman will auto-increment the current blobber and EC shard for you**

item.description:
The following requests detail the sharding, uploading and committing files to the network.

Steps 1 and 2 need only be performed once, Steps 3, 4 and 5 need to be performed as a group n times where n is the number of blobbers in the storage allocation.

eg.for an allocation with 4 blobbers:  
Run Steps 1 & 2 then  
for blobber 1 -> [Run Steps 3, 4, 5] then  
for blobber 2 -> [Run Steps 3, 4, 5] then  
for blobber 3 -> [Run Steps 3, 4, 5] then  
for blobber 4 -> [Run Steps 3, 4, 5]

Postman will switch to the next blobber and shard after the previous blobber has been comitted to successfully.


# Requirements
- Create a wallet
- Create an allocation

item.name: 👓 Lock read tokens

Ensure your SHA3-256 impl uses the SHA3 standard, not keccak-256 (which is what CryptoJS uses)

The API called within is not suitable for production calls and is provided without warranty.

request.description:
The following request asks the miners to create a read pool for a storage allocation.  
**This request can only be ran once per wallet**

**Requirements to make this request:**  
**Hash**
A SHA3-256 hash of a colon delimited string of [creation_date, client_id, to_client_id, transaction_value and the SHA3-256 hash of transaction_data]  
**Signature**
A BLS signature of the Hash  
**Client Id**
Your wallet id  
**Public Key**
The hex string of the BLS public key  
**Creation date**
The current unix epoch timestamp  
**To client Id**
The Id of the smart contract you wish to execute the transaction data on  
**Transaction data**
Data needed to create the initial pool

request.description:
The following request asks the miners to lock tokens in a given read pool  

**Requirements to make this request:**  
**Hash**
A SHA3-256 hash of a colon delimited string of [creation_date, client_id, to_client_id, transaction_value and the SHA3-256 hash of transaction_data]  
**Signature**
A BLS signature of the Hash  
**Client Id**
Your wallet id  
**Public Key**
The hex string of the BLS public key  
**Creation date**
The current unix epoch timestamp  
**To client Id**
The Id of the smart contract you wish to execute the transaction data on  
**Transaction data**
Read pool specific setup such as duration and allocation id goes here

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS
X-Requested-With, X-App-Client-ID, X-App-Client-Key, X-App-Signature, X-App-Timestamp, Content-Type, X-App-ID-TOKEN, X-App-Phone-Number, X-App-Client-Signature, x-app-id-token, x-app-phone-number

query.description: The read pool that we have requested be created

request.description: Similar to the create allocation and faucet requests, the lock read tokens request must be confirmed by a consensus of sharders before the read pool can be considered created.

query.description: The hash of the allocation that we have requested be created

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS
X-Requested-With, X-App-Client-ID, X-App-Client-Key, X-App-Signature, X-App-Timestamp, Content-Type, X-App-ID-TOKEN, X-App-Phone-Number, X-App-Client-Signature, x-app-id-token, x-app-phone-number

item.description:
On the 0chain network, there are two billable events when it comes to data: reads and writes.  
Locking tokens in a storage allocation automatically create a write pool which covers data writes eg. uploads.  

Data reads are covered by locking tokens in a read pool. A read pool is tied to an allocation and allows the data stored in that allocation to be read (downloaded or streamed).     

# Requirements
- Create a wallet
- create an allocation

item.name: 📥 Download a file

request.description:
Retrieve the storage allocation detail by performing a GET operation on the smart contract.  
The result of this will be important information we need such as the number of data and parity shards as well as the id and url of each blobber in the allocation, which is where our data is downloaded from.

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

item.name: 2. Get metadata of file to download

response.name: File does not exist
response.body: {"code":"invalid_parameters","error":"invalid_parameters: Invalid file path. record not found"}

item.name: 3. Get latest read marker on blobber for wallet's read pool

request.description:
The Read marker is another important feature of the network. 
It ensures that every download is recorded, tallied and transparent.  

Each blobber writes a read marker to the client's read pool when a file has been served.  
This ensures that blobbers are paid while keeping an audit.  

The read marker contains a counter of how many blocks have been read from the current blobber by the current pool, as well as the allocation  id the read was requested from.  

All Allocations use the same read pool.

At the point of download, a new read marker is written with an incremented counter

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS

response.name: successful operation - no read marker written yet

header.value: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS
X-Requested-With, X-App-Client-ID, X-App-Client-Key, X-App-Signature, X-App-Timestamp, Content-Type, X-App-ID-TOKEN, X-App-Phone-Number, X-App-Client-Signature, x-app-id-token, x-app-phone-number

exec: pm.test("Response code is 200 and data returned", function () {
pm.expect.fail("Download failed - latest write marker returned, use it in subsequent calculations")
// once the correct number of shards have been downlaoded we have enough to resonstruct the file and do not need to download the remaining parity shards
console.log("Blobbers have successfully been downloaded from, resetting to bloebber 0")
Ensure your SHA3-256 impl uses the standard, not keccak-256 (which is what CryptoJS uses)
This function is for illustration/testing purposes only.
The API called within is not suitable for production calls and is provided without warranty.

- Run this for as many data shards as you have
- success will return raw data
- failure will return latest write marker

response.body: This is a raw data shard! The rest of th%n

item.name: 5. Erasure decode file shards into single file

request.description:
This is not a 0chain API call but analogous of the processing one would do using their given programming language to assemble the shards into a single file

After downloading individual EC shards from the blobbers, these must be re-assembled back into a single file.  

Think of this as the reverse of the upload stage.

item.description:
The following requests detail the downloading and re-assembly of shards into a single file.

Steps 2, 3 and 4 need to be performed as a group n times where n is the number of data shards in the storage allocation.

eg.for an allocation with 2 data shards:  
Run Step 1 then  
for blobber 1 -> [Run Steps 2, 3, 4] then   
for blobber 2 -> [Run Steps 2, 3, 4] then   
Run step 5 to re-assemble the downloaded shards into a complete file.  
Postman will switch to the next blobber and shard after the previous blobber has been downloaded from.


# Requirements
- Create a wallet
- create an allocation
- upload a file
- lock read tokens

In fact, an auth ticket can be generated offline if you already know details of the file you wish to share.

response.name: already a collaborator

formdata.description: The wallet id you wish to share your file with

variable.description: The allocation id which contains the file you wish to share

item.description:
Files can be shared with other wallets on the 0chain network using 2 strategies:  
- creating an auth ticket for a file or
- Adding a collaborator to the file

The auth ticket contains information such as the content to be shared, who to share the content with (or indeed whether to share it with anyone), and how long to share it.  
The resultant JSON blob is Base-64 encoded for easy transport and can be used against many API endpoints directly, or using the 0box UI by navigating to 
https://{{network}}/0box/hash/{{auth_ticket}}

Adding a collaborator to a file provides similar access to that file as an auth ticket for a given wallet without needing to supply the ticket itself.

# Requirements
**Sender:**
- Create a wallet
- create an allocation
- upload a file  
**Consumer:**
- Create a wallet

Below are working, dynamic examples which you can try out with any valid test data.  
To start, import the collection and environment by clicking  

[![Run in Postman](https://run.pstmn.io/button.svg)](https://app.getpostman.com/run-collection/f5cdaa129ec7d319f06d?action=collection%2Fimport#?env%5B0Chain%20Devnet%201%)   

**Then switch to the 0Chain environment and edit the 'mnemonic' variable to match your 24-Word BIP39 Secret phrase**, or you can generate one [here](https://iancoleman.io/bip39/)

After that you are ready to go 🥳

**A note on the examples:**  
- The examples run against 0Chain Betanet by default. There are multiple test networks, not all are active at any one time:   
[beta.0chain.net](https://beta.0chain.net)  
[devnet.0chain.net](https://devnet.0chain.net)  
if you encounter issues with Beta or devnet, feel free to clone the environment and set the "network" variable to one of the other networks.
- Each request is listed a single time for brevity, but in production a given request may need to be sent multiple times.  
For example, in production, requests to miners and sharders should be sent to multiple nodes on the network to guarantee that the operation has been propagated.   
Upload and download operations require calls to multiple blobbers.   
In practice, these multiple calls could be ran concurrently.

- The examples are purposely basic and are not intended to cover every use case or feature. If you have a use case that you would like covered, please let us know and we will add it if we think it could be useful to others.

- If you would like more information on how the request data is generated, see the pre-request and test scripts for each request in postman.
